SpNote.note:
The intention of this library is to provide a series of templates which can be used by investigators to prepare their observing programs. The library is split into two sections:
(a) templates for a selection of routine observations that can be dragged and copied over to be used to create an observing program. (b) examples of how existing (shortened) SCUBA programs (previously referred to as observing templates) translate into OT-based MSBs.
The templates and examples should be relatively self-eplanatory, and of course can be readily taylored to fit the exact requirements of the SCUBA science program.
SpNote.title: Introductory note on SCUBA libraries and examples

SpNote.note: This folder contains templates that should be used for calibration purposes. Here, we have provided examples of the most common modes. Tayloring of examples to the needs of individual programs, for example modifying the chop throw/angle, is straight forward. More involved templates will be included in future releases.
SpNote.title: Introductory notes on the SCUBA calibration library templates

SpNote.note:
This observation provides an example of calibration at 850/450um of the photometry observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. A number of parameters have been assumed/predetermined, as listed below: - the bolometers to be calibrated have been set to H7 on the LONG array and C14 on the SHORT array, with the 850W/450W um filter wheel setting selected. - a chop throw of 60" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence) - 6 integrations (set in the PHOTOM eye)
A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last FOCUS/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Template notes

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration at 750/350um of the photometry observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and the precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. A number of parameters have been assumed/predetermined, as listed below: - the bolometers to be calibrated have been set to H7 on the LONG array and C14 on the SHORT array, with the 750W/350W um filter wheel setting selected. - a chop throw of 60" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence) - 6 integrations (set in the PHOTOM eye) A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Template notes

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration at 2000 um of the photometry observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. A number of parameters have been assumed/predetermined, as listed below: - the bolometer to be calibrated is the 2000 um pixel. - a chop throw of 60" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence) - 6 integrations (set in the PHOTOM eye) A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Template notes

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration at 1350 um of the photometry observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. A number of parameters have been assumed/predetermined, as listed below: - the bolometer to be calibrated is the 1350 um pixel. - a chop throw of 60" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence) - 6 integrations (set in the PHOTOM eye) A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration at 1100 um of the photometry observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. A number of parameters have been assumed/predetermined, as listed below: - the bolometer to be calibrated is the 1100 um pixel. - a chop throw of 60" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence) - 6 integrations (set in the PHOTOM eye) A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration of the jiggle map observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. Data from both the LONG and SHORT arrays will be stored, with the 850W/450W um filter selected. A 64-position jiggle pattern will be employed to obtain a fully sampled map at both LONG and SHORT wavelengths. A number of parameters have been assumed/predetermined, as listed below: - maps map with both arrays will be fully sampled - a chop throw of 120" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence) - 2 integrations (set in the JIGGLE eye) A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note:
This observation provides an example of calibration of the jiggle map observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. Data from both the LONG and SHORT arrays will be stored, with the 850W/450W um filter selected. A 16-position jiggle pattern will be employed, so ONLY data taken with the LONG array will be fully sampled. A number of parameters have been assumed/predetermined, as listed below: - only the map taken with the LONG array will be fully sampled - a chop throw of 120" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence) - 2 integrations (set in the JIGGLE eye)
A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration of the jiggle map observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. Data from both the LONG and SHORT arrays will be stored, with the 850W/450W um filter selected. A 16-position jiggle pattern will be employed, so ONLY data taken with the SHORT array will be fully sampled. A number of parameters have been assumed/predetermined, as listed below: - only the map taken with the SHORT array will be fully sampled - a chop throw of 120" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence) - 2 integrations (set in the JIGGLE eye) A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration of the scan map observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. Data from both the LONG and SHORT arrays will be stored, with the 850/450 um filter selected. The standard Emerson2 chop sequence has been assumed here, with 2 chop angles at each of 3 different chop throws. A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration of the scan map observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. Data is taken using the 2000 um bolometer. The standard Emerson2 chop sequence has been assumed here, with 2 chop angles at each of 3 different chop throws. A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpObs.title: 850 um jiggle map (fully sampled at 850 um ONLY): polarimetry calibration

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration of the jiggle map observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. Data from the LONG and SHORT arrays will be stored, with the 850/450 um filter selected, however only data taken with the LONG array will be fully-sampled. A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpObs.title: 450 um jiggle map (fully sampled at 450 um ONLY): polarimetry calibration

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration of the jiggle map observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. Data from the LONG and SHORT arrays will be stored, with the 850/450 um filter selected, however only data taken with the SHORT array will be fully-sampled. A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation is an example of the sequence of tasks required to make a measurement of the instrumental polarization at 850 um.This is one of the rare examples when a calibration source needs to be defined explicitly. Here an unpolarized source is required, ideally either Mars or Uranus (a little small, angular size-wise). In this example all polarization angles are measured for a single chop throw before moving to the next chop setting. A pointing, z-focus and repoint are also include (POINTING eye and FOCUS respectively) as is a skydip.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation is an example of the sequence of tasks required to make a measurement of the instrumental polarization at 450 um.This is one of the rare examples when a calibration source needs to be defined explicitly. Here an unpolarized source is required, ideally either Mars or Uranus (a little small, angular size-wise). In this example all polarization angles are measured for a single chop throw before moving to the next chop setting. A pointing, z-focus and repoint are also include (POINTING eye and FOCUS respectively) as is a skydip.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This folder contains templates that provide the basic blocks with which to build up MSBs and ultimately observing programs. Examples of both MSBs and simple observing programs are shown in the examples library. Here we have tried to provide examples of most common observing modes, with tayloring to specific chop throws and integration times easily done.
SpNote.title: Introductory notes on the SCUBA templates

SpNote.note: This observation is an example of the sequence of tasks required to make an 850/450um photometry observation.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation is an example of the sequence of tasks required to make a 750/350 um photometry observation.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation is an example of the sequence of tasks required to make a photometry observation using the 2000 um bolometer.

SpNote.note: This observation is an example of the sequence of tasks required to make a photometry observation at 1100 um.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation is an example of the sequence of tasks required to make an 850 um polarimetry photometry observation. Note that this observation will be made without any jiggling of the secondary.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation is an example of the sequence of tasks required to make a 450um polarimetry photometry observation. Note that this observation will be made without any jiggling of the secondary mirror.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: This observation is an example of the sequence of tasks required to make an 850/450um photometry observation.
SpNote.title: Observation notes

SpNote.note: Scan map polarimetry is a difficult observing mode in which to obtain high quality data. The limiting factor becomes that of sky variability. In this mode we have assumed that it is optimal to make 4 raster scans instead of the usual 6 that are employed for the Emerson2 scanning scheme, and that the 4 scans are made for each of the polarization grid angles. Under some circumstances it may be preferable to make observations at each of the grid angles before moving to a different scan throw/angle.
